docs.lead_paragraph: Think of it as the fight for the Bionic Baby Boomer. From head to toe, aging boomers are being kept alive and kicking -- or at least walking -- by an expanding array of devices that combine the newest medical knowledge with the latest breakthroughs in digital electronics and material sciences.

headline.main: To Order Spare Parts Press *P; Medical Devices Are Hot, Which Is Why Guidant Is

docs.snippet: As wave after wave of baby boomers enter their prime health care spending years, the medical device market is expected to grow by double digits for years to come.

multimedia.credit: Here are some 2006 revenue forecasts in some fast-growing medical device markets and sample products.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Here are some 2006 revenue forecasts in some fast-growing medical device markets and sample products.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''I pleaded with my sister, Susan, to get genetic testing, but she refused,'' a woman recently told me in my office. Susan, the woman said, already had breast cancer, so her health insurance company would have paid for the testing.

headline.main: Genetic Testing Creates New Versions of Ancient Dilemmas

docs.abstract: Dr Robert Klitzman Cases column discusses difficult medical decisions associated with learning results of genetic tests; holds that genetic test results can be misleading and do not always provide definitive link to developing disease; compares understanding test results to ancient Greeks interpreting oracles of future; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: In the new genetic age, the notion that family members are "bound by ties of blood" takes on new meaning.

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S sick, the way Americans think about illness. A disease like diabetes gallops practically out of control, with estimates that 21 million Americans have it and 45 million more could develop it. Yet relatively few people worry about it or alter their behavior to postpone or possibly prevent its onset.

headline.main: On Not Wanting to Know What Hurts You

docs.snippet: A disease like diabetes gallops practically out of control, yet relatively few people worry about it or alter their behavior to postpone or possibly prevent its onset.

docs.lead_paragraph: Khamla Sengdavong, the manager of a state-owned farm here, still remembers his horror and dismay when bird flu suddenly killed a quarter of the farm's 2,000 chickens in five days in January 2004. ''They bled from the nose and the backs of their heads turned purple and then black, and then they died,'' he said, gesturing with his hands.

headline.main: Laos, Apparently Without Bird Flu, Is Still Pressed by the West to Join Global Fight

docs.abstract: Bird flu made brief appearance in Laos in January 2004 and seems to have quickly disappeared without causing any human fatalities; Laos and other poor countries have become front lines in global effort against bird flu and are under international pressure to manage extensive programs to combat bird flu although they have struggled to marshal enough doctors and veterinarians to combat diseases in best of times; health experts are starting to raise questions about trade-offs; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Facing a potential world epidemic of bird flu, health officials in Laos are setting aside local priorities.
